children.name: not on time
children.definition: not arriving or leaving at the time that was arranged:

children.name: không đúng giờ
examples: ▪ The buses are never on time.
▪ She knew if she wasn’t on time that day she’d lose her job.
▪ If we don’t leave on time, we’ll miss the flight!

children.name: late
children.definition: arriving or leaving after the time that was arranged:

children.name: trễ , muộn
examples: ▪ Andrew arrived late, as usual.

children.name: be late
examples: ▪ Sorry I’m late - my car wouldn’t start.

children.name: late for
examples: ▪ She often arrives late for work.

children.name: 5 minutes/2 days etc late
examples: ▪ As usual, the bus was half an hour late.

children.name: late arrival/departure
examples: ▪ We apologize for the late arrival of Flight AZ709.

children.name: latecomer
children.definition: someone who arrives after the time that something such as a meeting, play, or concert is supposed to start:

children.name: người đến muộn
examples: ▪ Latecomers will not be allowed into the concert hall until the interval.

children.name: what you say when sb or st is late
what kept you ?
children.definition: what kept you?spokensay this when someone arrives late and you are alittleannoyed:
examples: ▪ ‘What kept you?’ ‘I couldn’t find my glasses.’

children.name: where have you been ?
children.definition: where have you been? spoken say this when someone arrives very late and you want to know why, because you areworriedorannoyed:
examples: ▪ Where have you been? You said you’d be here at three!

children.name: about time too
children.definition: British /it’s about timeAmerican spokensay this when someone or something arrives or does something late, and you areannoyedbecause you have been waiting a long time:
examples: đến giờ rồi , trễ rồi
▪ ‘Look, here’s the bus.’ ‘It’s about time!’

children.name: what time do you call this?
children.definition: British spoken say this when you areannoyedwithsomeonebecause they have arrived very late:
examples: ▪ What time do you call this, Martin? You were supposed to be here half an hour ago.

children.name: better late than never
children.definition: say this when someone or something arrives or does something late but it does not matter very much:
examples: trễ còn hơn không
▪ ‘The pictures have finally arrived.’ ‘Well, better late than never.’

children.name: is that the time?
children.definition: British say this when you suddenly realize that it is later than you thought it was:

children.name: trễ mất rồi
examples: ▪ Oh my god, is that the time? I’ve got to go!

children.name: you’re late
children.definition: use this when someone arrives somewhere late:
examples: ▪ You’re late! Hurry up and get your books out and get on with your work.
▪ You’re late again, Chris! You’ll be in trouble if you don’t get your act together soon.

children.name: the middle of the night
children.definition: late at night when most people are asleep:

children.name: nửa đêm
examples: ▪ In the middle of the night, I was woken by a loud noise downstairs.

children.name: ▪ Helen opened the door. ‘Dave? What’s wrong? It’s the middle of the night!’
late
examples: it’s late
▪ Look, it’s late and I’m tired - let’s talk about this tomorrow.
it’s getting late : muộn rồi
▪ I must go home now, it’s getting late.
late at night
▪ I don’t like coming home late at night to an empty house.
stay up late : thức khuya
not go to bed until late
▪ They stayed up late to watch the end of the match.
have a late night : đi ngủ trễ
when you go to bed very late
▪ You look as if you’ve been having too many late nights recently.

children.name: late-night
children.definition: happening or shown late at night:
examples: ▪ They kept us awake with their late-night parties.

children.name: ▪ late-night television
examples: ▪ They stopped off for a late-night drink.

children.name: last thing at night
children.definition: just before you go to bed:
examples: ▪ The soldiers are supposed to polish their shoes last thing at night.

children.name: the early hours
children.definition: a time which is very late at night, between about 1 o'clock and 4 o'clock in the morning:
examples: ▪ The club didn’t close till the early hours.

children.name: the early hours of the morning
examples: ▪ They reached San Francisco in the early hours of the morning.

children.name: till all hours
children.definition: until very late at night - use this when you are annoyed by someone doing something too late at night:
examples: ▪ She and her friends used to stay out till all hours, going from club to club.
▪ Better not wake her - she was up till all hours last night, working.

children.name: miss
children.definition: to arrive too late to see an event, film etc, or too late to get on a plane, train etc:

children.name: bỏ lỡ
examples: ▪ You’d better hurry or you’ll miss the start of the show.

children.name: miss the flight/train/bus/ferry
examples: ▪ I missed the bus and had to wait half an hour for the next one.

children.name: too late
children.definition: so late that you cannot do or achieve what you had planned:
examples: ▪ I’m afraid you’re too late - I’ve just sold the last ticket.

children.name: arrive/finish etc too late
examples: ▪ We rushed to the store as soon as we left work but arrived too late.

children.name: too late to do something
examples: ▪ They got to the airport too late to catch the plane.

children.name: it is too late (to do something)
examples: ▪ By the time the doctor arrived, it was too late; he was already dead.
▪ It’s never too late to learn a new language.

children.name: it’s a little late
children.definition: alsoa bit late in the dayBritish spokenyou say it’s a little late when someone decides to do something butharmhas already been done or there is no time left to do it:

children.name: it’s a little late for
examples: ▪ Perhaps it’s a bit late in the day for apologies.

children.name: it’s a little late to do something
examples: ▪ It’s a little late to start worrying about that now.

children.name: leave it too late
children.definition: /a bit lateBritish alsolet it go too longAmerican   to wait too long before doing something so that you are not likely to achieve what you hoped to achieve:
examples: ▪ At last the government has decided to lower interest rates, but I think they’ve let it go too long.

children.name: leave it too late/a bit late to do something
examples: ▪ You might have left it a bit too late to apply for a place at university for this academic year.

children.name: late
examples: muộn , trễ ( hơn thông thường )
▪ The library stays open late on Fridays.
be late
▪ The harvest was late this year because of the bad weather.
work latestay at work till later than usual
▪ I’m afraid I’ll have to work late again tomorrow.
get up late
▪ It’s really nice to get up late on Saturday mornings.
a late breakfast/lunch etc
▪ ‘Where’s Bill?’ ‘He’s having a late lunch.’

children.name: late in life
children.definition: if you do something late in life, you do it when you areolderthan the age at which people usually do it:

children.name: muộn ( so với tuổi )
examples: ▪ Greg got married late in life.
▪ Carter and Reagan had come into politics relatively late in life.

children.name: When st happens later than it should
trễ
examples: ▪ The meeting started late.
▪ There are severe penalties for late payment of bills.

children.name: 15 minutes/3 days etc late
examples: ▪ Tony handed in his homework a day late.

children.name: overdue
children.definition: use this aboutpaymentsthat should have been made orlibrarybooksthat should have been returned before now:

children.name: quá hạn
examples: ▪ I must take these books back to the library - they’re overdue.

children.name: three weeks/two months etc overdue
examples: ▪ The rent’s three weeks overdue.

children.name: be behind with st
children.definition: be behind with  to have not made one or more regularpaymentsat the time when you should:
examples: nợ
▪ Jim’s worried because he’s behind with his loan repayments.
be two months etc behind with something
▪ You’re two months behind with the rent.
get/fall behind with something
start to make payments late
▪ I’m getting behind with the mortgage and I don’t know how I’m going to pay it.
▪ Even when people fall behind with their payments, they continue to take on financial commitments.

children.name: be in arrears
children.definition: to have not made one or more regularpaymentsat the time when you should:

children.name: trễ
examples: ▪ In some areas, two out of three tenants are in arrears.

children.name: be in arrears with
examples: ▪ Many countries are in arrears with their contributions.

children.name: be two months etc in arrears
examples: ▪ Over 60,000 Londoners are more than three months in arrears with their mortgage repayments.

children.name: get/fall into arrears
examples: ▪ The tax bills are sent out annually, so it’s very easy for small employers to fall into arrears.

children.name: belated
children.definition: doneorgivenlater than it should have been, usually with the result that it does not have the effect that it should have:

children.name: muộn , trễ
examples: ▪ John made a belated attempt to apologize.
▪ I got a belated birthday card from my cousin yesterday.

children.name: ▪ her belated realisation that he was in love with someone else
to have done less than you planned to do
be behind
children.definition: to have done less of your work than you planned to do or should have done:
examples: ▪ If you’re so far behind that you can’t finish it on time, give me a call and I’ll come and help.
be behind with
▪ I’ve got to stay late tonight because I’m a bit behind with my work.'
get behind
▪ If you don’t do your homework every week, you’ll get behind in your studies.
way behindvery much behind
▪ We were way behind on the budget planning already when the new project came in.

children.name: be behind schedule
children.definition: to be doing each part of a planned series of activities later than you planned to do it:
examples: ▪ Sorry, I can’t talk now - I’m behind schedule as it is.

children.name: be six months etcbehind schedule
examples: ▪ The tunnel project is now 18 months behind schedule and £300 million over budget.

children.name: be running late
children.definition: to have spent longer than planned doing the first part of something or the first of a series of activities:
examples: ▪ We’re running late - we’ll have to hurry if we want to catch the 5 o'clock train.
▪ The Queen’s visit to the factory was running late, so she did not come to see the production department.
